title: 105_hr3723
content: The Act titled "United States Patent and Trademark Office Reauthorization Act, Fiscal Year 1999" authorizes $66,000,000 for the Patent and Trademark Office's expenses in fiscal year 1999. Fees collected in fiscal year 1998 and 1999, as per title 35, United States Code, and the Trademark Act of 1946, will fund these expenses. The fees collected will remain available until expended. The Commissioner shall charge various fees for patent applications and issuance, including $760 for filing an original patent application, additional fees for excess claims, $150 for a provisional application, and $1,210 for issuing a patent. Design and plant cases have specific fees as well. The fees for patent applications and issuance include $480 for filing each plant application, $430 for issuing each design patent, $580 for issuing each plant patent, $760 for filing an application for patent reissue, $110 for filing a disclaimer, $300 for filing an appeal to the Board of Patent Appeals and Interferences, and additional fees for excess claims. The fees for petitions related to patent applications range from $110 to $490, with exceptions for specific types of petitions. Additionally, the basic national fee for certain international applications is $670. The basic national fee for international applications varies depending on the involvement of the Patent and Trademark Office, ranging from $760 to $970. Additionally, a fee of $96 is required for international applications meeting specific criteria in the preliminary examination report. The national stage fees for filing independent claims in excess of 3 is $78, for filing claims in excess of 20 is $18, and for multiple dependent claims is $260. Errors in fee payment can be corrected as per regulations. Patent maintenance fees are amended in section 41 of title 35, United States Code. The Commissioner shall charge fees for maintaining patents based on application filing dates. Failure to pay maintenance fees will result in patent expiration. A surcharge may be required for late payments. Maintenance fees for design or plant patents are not applicable. The text chunk discusses the authorization of fee collection by the Commissioner for the Patent and Trademark Office. Fees collected will be used for office activities. The effective date for this Act and its amendments is October 1, 1998.
